Yes, I understand the information you provided about General Conditions, Clause 4. Essential matters. This clause outlines the essential information that the owner must provide to the builder before the building works can commence. Failure to provide this information within the initial period may result in the builder ending the contract and the owner being liable for the services provided and works carried out to that point. The main topics and subtopics that could be written for homeowners are as follows: | Main Topic | Subtopics | | --- | --- | | Essential information required by the builder | - Proof of ownership or entitlement to build on the site
- Details of any encumbrances, covenants, easements, and caveats affecting the site
- Evidence of establishment of the security account and the required amount
- Evidence of sufficient finance to pay the contract price
- Evidence of development consent for the building works
- Proof of building approvals and satisfaction of conditions imposed by statutory or other authority
- Appointment of the principal certifying authority and payment of associated costs
- Satisfaction of other statutory obligations | | Consequences of failure to provide essential information | - Builder may end the contract
- Owner liable for services provided and works carried out to that point
- Owner must pay the builder's margin applied to the costs incurred, including non-returnable materials | These topics and subtopics will provide homeowners with a clear understanding of the information they need to provide to the builder before the building works can commence and the consequences of failing to do so.
